respStmt.resp: Encoded in TEI P5 XML by
respStmt.name: Danny Smith

availability.p: The Global Medieval Sourcebook is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-Noncommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International License.

notesStmt.p: The Millstatt Plaint of Sin, written in middle of the twelfth century perhaps in the South West of Germany, is a substantial poem addressed to God in the voice of a sinner. The poem is conventionally counted as part of a small sub-genre of Early Middle High German religious poetry known as the “Sündenklage”, or “plaint of sin”. These poems – there is also the Vorau Plaint of Sin and the more simplistic Uppsala Plaint of Sin – all have at their heart a confession of sinfulness and a prayer to God for mercy, and are thought to have taken their inspiration from the more pragmatic text-type of the German confession (“Beichte”). These confessions, generalized first-person confessions in prose, are transmitted widely from the ninth century and had a variety of liturgical and devotional functions.

The manuscript of the Millstatt Plaint of Sin is heavily damaged, but it is nonetheless possible to get a good sense of the poem and its themes. It is not simply a confession of sins, but rather offers a conceptualization of the world, as well as the place of man and his sins within it. By framing the confessional act with sections praising God and his creation and structuring sins around the inappropriate use of individual body parts, the Millstatt Plaint of Sin explains that God is in everything and that all created things are a way of seeing God; hence sinning is perceived as an almost illogical malfunctioning of creation. Although ostensibly quite straightforward, the poem tackles – in a rewarding and indeed quite challenging way – a number of contemporary issues that will be of interest to readers: the relationship between body and soul; bodily fragmentation; and the nature and construction of selfhood.

The Millstatt Plaint of Sin is transmitted in full in Klagenfurt Landesarchiv Cod. GV 6/19, a major anthology of “Early Middle High German” verse texts. It was made around 1200, or slightly later, in Bavaria or Austria, and contains the Old German Genesis, Exodus, and Physiologus, accompanied by illustrations, followed by five short religious poems, of which the Millstatt Plaint of Sin is the third. We do not know for whom it was made – perhaps for nobility or for a female religious community. The part of the manuscript containing our poem is heavily damaged and so the poem itself is often difficult to reconstruct. Some insight into the missing sections is, however, offered by two other manuscript witnesses that contain fragmented versions of the same poem: 1) Munich BSB Cgm 5249/60a, four parchment fragments of Honorius’ Elucidarium from the late twelfth century, with a German text written below in a smaller hand (although perhaps the same hand) that correlates – albeit with considerable deviation – to around 100 lines of the Millstatt Plaint of Sin; 2) Zurich Zentralbibliothek Cod. Rh. 77, a ninth- or tenth-century Latin manuscript with various twelfth-century additions, including a fragment of a German poem often known as the Rheinau Paul. This poem correlates fairly closely to parts of the end of the Millstatt Plaint of Sin, although it is by no means identical.
Bynum, Caroline W. Fragmentation and Redemption: Essays on Gender and the Human Body in Medieval Religion. Zone Books, 2012.
A key work on medieval approaches to the body, the relationship between body and soul and bodily fragmentation.

Haug, Walter. "Literature, allegory and salvation: theoretical positions in Early Middle High German," in Haug, Vernacular Literary Theory in the Middle Ages. translated by Joanna M. Catling, Cambridge Studies in Medieval Literature, 29. Cambridge UP, 1997, pp. 46–74.
A introduction to the content and style of German religious poetry of the twelfth century, focusing on salvation and praise.
Schneider, Karin, "117. Beitrag: Ein Weiterer Textzeuge Der 'Millstätter Sündenklage.'" Zeitschrift für deutsches Altertum und deutsche Literatur vol. 124, no. 3, S. Hirzel Verlag, 1995, pp. 298–302.
A transcription and description of the fragmented Munich manuscript.

Schröder, Werner. Vom 'Rheinauer Paulus' zur 'Millstätter Sündenklage': Aspekte der Poetisierung volkssprachlicher kirchlicher Gebrauchstexte im frühen 12. Jahrhundert. Akademie der Wissenschaften und der Literatur/Steiner Verlag Wiesbaden, 1986. Reprinted in Schröder Werner, Frühe Schriften zur Ältesten deutschen Literatur, Schriften der wissenschaftlichen Gesellschaft an der Johann Wolfgang Goethe-Universität Frankfurt am Main, Geisteswissenschaftliche Reihe, 13. Steiner, 1999, pp. 255–322.
The only detailed study of the Millstatt Plaint of Sin.

projectDesc.p: "The Millstatt Plaint of Sin" is published by The Global Medieval Sourcebook (GMS), a free, open access, and open source compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. GMS comprises computer-readable transcriptions or editions alongside new translations of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia. The GMS platform includes critical introductions as well as sources for further reading.

editorialDecl.p: Transcriptions and translations are encoded in XML conforming to TEI (P5) guidelines. The original-language text is contained within <lem> tags and translations within <rdg> tags.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern American English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Scribal errors and creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

Previous editors of the Millstatt Plaint of Sin have made attempts to reconstruct the damaged poem using a mix of the so-called Rheinau Paul and educated guesswork. I have largely avoided the latter, although not because I think earlier attempts were not plausible: both Roediger and Maurer make thoughtful, intelligent suggestions. Roediger often underestimates the size of the gaps, however, and Maurer’s edition, although largely more plausible, is marred by his insistence on a long-line strophic form, for which there is little evidence. I have only completed half-finished words when their full form is entirely obvious, and these instances are indicated by italicization. I have, however, completed some lines using the Munich and (particularly) the Zurich manuscripts above – these instances are italicized and marked with square brackets (Munich) and curly brackets (Zurich). I have avoided any linguistic normalization, though; my aim in ‘completing’ these lines is to give the reader a (plausible) sense of the content, not to recreate a damaged poem. In any case, the verses in the Munich and Zurich manuscripts do show considerable differentiation to those in the Klagenfurt manuscript, so my additions should not be thought of as anything other than possibilities. I use | to mark the end of a folio in the Klagenfurt manuscript.

app.rdg: you, who are a true God,
master of the guardian of hell.
You are God of the heavens:

app.lem: div nimet abe so du wil

app.rdg: this is how you are described!

app.lem: uns bist doch der ewige got
app.rdg: and you are yet also eternal God!

app.lem: unde bist doch bein unde uleisch
app.rdg: and are yet bone and flesh.

app.lem: Dv bist lewe du bist lamp
app.rdg: You are lion, you are lamb,

app.lem: du bist churz du bist lanch
app.rdg: you are short, you are long.

app.lem: dv bist rich du bist arm
app.rdg: You are rich, you are poor,

app.lem: dui bist chalt du bist warm
app.rdg: you are cold, you are warm.

app.lem: du bist lip du bist tot
app.rdg: You are life, you are death,

app.lem: du bist suozze du bist scharf
app.rdg: You are sweet, you are sharp,

app.lem: du bist weich du bist starch
app.rdg: you are soft, you are strong.

app.lem: di bist uinster du bist lieht
app.rdg: You are darkness, you are light,

app.lem: du bist leit du bist liep
app.rdg: you are sorrow, you are love.

app.lem: du bist blode du bist balt
app.rdg: You are weak, you are brave,

app.lem: du bist iunch du bist alt
app.rdg: you are young, you are old.
How did you put up with me
when I turned away from you?

app.lem: nu bitte ich iuch namen dri
app.rdg: Now I beg you in your threefold name,
although I am unworthy of it,
For I wish to acknowledge you.
in the name of the love of your mother,
and in [….] that you gave to Abraham,
for I have followed the example of

app.lem: daz er im sinen teil gap
unde mit sunden so gar uerswante
app.rdg: and, in sin, wasted so entirely

app.lem: do begunde er halten div swin
app.rdg: Then he began to keep pigs –

app.lem: Die wrzzen die daz swin group
app.rdg: The roots that the pigs dug up

app.lem: daz er sich da mit nerte

app.rdg: Then the poor man thought to himself:

app.lem: waz ob ich minen uater erbarme
app.rdg: what if I might cause my father to feel pity

app.lem: daz ich im hate div swin
app.rdg: by keeping his pigs for him?
have plenty of bread and wine.

app.lem: waz ob ich bin so sælich
app.rdg: What if I am so blessed
because he felt compassion for him.
In truth, we sinners are not able to […]
all the bottom of the sea,

app.lem: ulivhe ich an daz meres ort
app.rdg: If I were to flee to the bottom of the sea

app.lem: da uindet mich daz din wort
wie schiere ez mich da uindet
app.rdg: how quickly it would find me there!
The wood has not a single tree

app.lem: dune wizzent wol wa er stat
app.rdg: whose location is unknown to you.
And also the dark pine forest –
no man would ever be able to
If I were to flee into one,

app.lem: da uindet mich daz wort din

app.rdg: so that it was lacking in nothing.
In this way you are a just judge […]
nor claim to land, nor taxes:
at that time […] in his power.
Then […] tongues are of no help,
nor the lord to his servant,
nor the servant to his lord,

app.lem: swie breit im sin div lehen
app.rdg: however much he owes to him.
The advocate is of no help –
for he dare not speak up there.

app.lem: swie harte uns unsir sunde riwe
app.rdg: However greatly we regret our sins,
There, there is weeping and wailing,

app.lem: so entuot in niweht so not
app.rdg: they could have no greater torment

app.lem: daz im daz sam we tuot
app.rdg: that it causes him as much pain

app.lem: sam daz uivr ioch div gluot
so grinet si an der satanat
app.rdg: This is how devilry howls at them:
no form of suffering is ignored.
this is what he offers there in hell.
They must sit there in the heat,

app.lem: da zuo git er in ouch

app.rdg: O woe that he was born!
If the world ever comes to an end,
In this way he calls them […]
the sun does not burn them,

app.lem: wan si schulen immir iugent han

app.rdg: in the song of the angels
There, there is a permanent state of complete grace.

app.lem: uil liep er in ze sehen ist
app.rdg: he is a joy for them to behold.
now go to into the Kingdom of Heaven
Thus there is great joy there

app.lem: Nu chum ich uater unde sun
app.rdg: So I approach, Father and Son,
how I might […] the same grace,

app.lem: so bin ich gescheidin uon iv […]
app.rdg: then I am separated from you […]

app.lem: wand ich der aller armist bin
app.rdg: because I am the man most devoid

app.lem: Ich wolde é sunten mit gewalte
app.rdg: I was accustomed to sin with violence,
I am your servant who has run away.

app.lem: uon div uurhte ich dinen slach
app.rdg: Because of this I feared your blows,
for I fled from your service
To places where people served you
I did not want to go.
Lord, that was a great thing,

app.lem: nu sihe ich wol daz ich enm[…]
app.rdg: Now I can see full well that I cannot […]
you who are my true father

app.lem: der ich dir nu chlagen wil
app.rdg: which I now wish to bewail to you
and will bring the written records
and there will make known all the advice
that he has given to me.

app.lem: die sint chomen in sine gewalt
app.rdg: have brought me into his power.
I fear, that if I put this off
then I would enter into great torment.
in the name of your mother,
so that he might make many men fall.

app.lem: da er si in hat ge[…]

app.rdg: very frequently, both day and night,
My feet were upright when it came to whores,

app.lem: ze roube was is so lipe

app.rdg: they did not follow the way of God.
when I was engaged in service to you,
I bring my feet to you as guilty
so that you might judge them
so that my soul will never enter
I pray for this through the binding ties
which you gave over to the Jews
for I have hope in you.

app.lem: in daz hor und in den […]

app.rdg: which the Jews gave to you
which they, contrary to your love,
I bring them to you as guilty.
I bewail this to you, Lord.
they never wanted to show them compassion
when you went to the cross,

app.lem: daz gebet daz der man tuot

app.rdg: if they do not come from the heart:
it would be better to remain silent.
I have been deceived by it.
and made a place in me
Set me free from these, God,
[…] might find none of these things,
in the name of the […] of your father,
and in the name of the […] of the holy cross,
If it did not want to […]

app.lem: so der lip lít in der […]
app.rdg: as the body suffers in the […].

app.lem: wan si uerswur sich aller teg[…]

app.rdg: those things it did against you.
with the result that my soul […]
I beg this of you in the name of the nails
through your hands and through your feet,
Now I want to speak of my ears,
did contrary to you by way of whores,
my ears brought this to me.
Lord, the ears were guilty of this.
Whenever anyone suggested theft to me,

app.lem: da was den oren so liep
app.rdg: this was music to my ears.
I turned my ears towards them,
they did not want to listen.
and went away from there with anger.
When I was supposed to pray,
in the cathedral or in church
You should judge them for this,

app.lem: durch die rede die du tæte
app.rdg: in the name of the words you spoke
when you died on the cross,
the eyes showed me the way.
my eyes showed me the way.
my eyes showed me the way.
through which my body might commit sin,
my eyes helped me to do it.
You should pass judgement on them […]
for it let these things happen ungladly.
that you suffered for my sake:

app.lem: daz han ich uerdient umbe dich
app.rdg: I have deserved this from you.
in the name of your holy […],
in the name of true loyalty,
as you listened to your maidservant,
that you might rouse Lazarus from his grave,
who had been buried for three days:
for this same sake I beg you
in the name of the holy death,
Lord, you died on the cross.
So that you might set all of your people
in the name of this very redemption
in the name of the holy grave
I have hope in your mercy
I bring myself to your threefold mercy.
We should think this a very good thing.
and through my desire for any kind of sin,
let my body take on responsibility
so that my soul be saved.
I pray to you for your grace,
in the name of your resurrection
and in the name of the path so blessed,
I urge you with your own words:
now fills me with great regret,
that you wanted to seek me,
so that they are not lost.
in the name of the living stones,
which is the home of the servants of hell.

app.lem: des bitte ich {dur die drie} chnaben
app.rdg: I pray for this in the name of the three youths,

app.lem: die du domine {beschirdos in deme glugindin hou}ene
app.rdg: whom you, Lord, protected in the fiery furnace.

app.lem: ia sagent uns div {buch daz misahel daz} dritte was
app.rdg: indeed the book tells us that the third was Misahel.
it was unable to burn them.
Your angel was there with them.
so that the fire was unable to touch them,
Now I beg you in the name of the three youths

app.lem: unde {daz du mich irlose}st dinen schalch
app.rdg: and to free me, your servant,
so that it may never burn so greatly!
so that they dared not touch him:
he was put in there with them,
so that the lions might tear him to pieces.

app.lem: daz die lewen | uon im uluhen
app.rdg: making the lions flee from him
until you, with the bread of Abacuchis,
set him free from that place.
and that you forgive me too
just as you behaved towards the woman,
so that they might order her to be stoned.
that she was worthy of death,

app.lem: {do lastos tu si uzir} michil not
app.rdg: Then you relieved her of great torment.

app.lem: do schribe d{u an der erde}
app.rdg: Then you wrote in the earth,
from casting a stone at her.
that she should never do it again,
that she should set sin aside.
She had great faith in you.
Now let me rejoice in her,
and in Daniel, and in the host of your prophets,
